.. _`bio/sleuth/lrt`:

SLEUTH_LRT
==========

Perform a likelyhood ration test



Example
-------

This wrapper can be used in the following way:

.. code-block:: python

    rule test_sleuth_lrt:
        input:
            rds = "wald_test.rds"
        output:
            rds = "lrt.rds"
        wrapper:
            "0.74.0-764-g3b0788731/bio/sleuth/lrt"

Note that input, output and log file paths can be chosen freely.
When running with

.. code-block:: bash

    snakemake --use-conda

the software dependencies will be automatically deployed into an isolated environment before execution.

Software dependencies
---------------------

* ``bioconda:r-sleuth``

Input/Output
------------
**Input:**

* RDS formatted sleuth object

**Output:**

* RDS formatted sleuth object with fitted model




Authors
-------

* Thibault Dayris


Code
----

.. code-block:: R

    #!/bin/R

    # Snakemake wrapper for sleuth lrt
    # __author__ = "Thibault Dayris"
    # __copyright__ = "Copyright 2020, Thibault Dayris"
    # __email__ = "thibault.dayris@gustaveroussy.fr"
    # __license__ = "MIT"

    base::library(package = "sleuth", quietly = TRUE);

    threads <- snakemake@threads;
    mc.cores <- threads;
    options(mc.cores = threads);

    so <- base::readRDS(
        file = snakemake@input[["rds"]]
    );

    extra <- "";
    if ("extra" %in% names(snakemake@params)) {
      extra <- base::as.character(
        x = snakemake@params[["extra"]]
      );
    }

    command <- base::paste(
      "sleuth::sleuth_lrt(",
      "obj = so",
      extra,
      ")",
      sep = ", "
    );

    ## Finally run sleuth prep
    so_lrt <- base::eval(
      base::parse(
        text = command
      )
    );


    base::saveRDS(
      object = so_lrt,
      file = snakemake@output[["rds"]]
    );
